item.title: Football Manager will officially licence The Premier League
item.content:encoded:
https://www.eurogamer.net/football-manager-will-officially-licence-the-premier-league

Football Manager developer Sports Interactive has announced a four-year licensing partnership with The Premier League.

It means, for the first time ever, Football Manager players will be able to take their team to the top of English football, with all 20 clubs fully licensed including official logos, kits, and player photos.

The deal will begin with the 2024/25 season, due later this year.

"Since Football Manager's inception, we have always wanted to work with the Premier League, and we're delighted to announce today that at last we are", said Sports Interactive studio director Miles Jacobson.

"The partnership isn't just about the huge in-game benefits it'll give our fans, but also the opportunities it provides us to help with the incredible things that the Premier League and their clubs do off the pitch. That includes community and charitable work, two things we're enormously passionate about, as well as the ability to work with some of their existing partners.

"We are very grateful to the Premier League and their other partners in our space for enabling us to be an officially licensed product of the world's most commercially successful football league."

Premier League chief commercial officer Will Brass added: "Football Manager has been a big part of the sporting landscape for decades, and is loved and enjoyed by millions of fans around the world. We are thrilled that the Premier League will now feature even more prominently in the game, helping to deliver a deeper, more authentic experience for anybody who takes on the challenge of managing a Premier League club."

Football Manager first released in 2005, after its previous iteration as Championship Manager that began in 1992. It's surprising, therefore, it's taken so long for The Premier League to be officially licensed.

"What should be a transitional year for Football Manager feels like a quietly revolutionary one, thanks to a handful of little changes with big impacts," reads Eurogamer's Football Manager 2024 review.

item.title: NO Nintendo Direct This Week, Journalist Claims; Said to Air Later This Month
item.content:encoded:
https://wccftech.com/no-nintendo-direct-this-week-journalist-claims-said-to-air-later-this-month/

There won't be a Nintendo Direct broadcast this week, a known Brazilian Journalist has claimed.

Despite rumors claiming otherwise, Nintendo won't be airing a new Direct episode later this week. Luckily for Nintendo fans, however, there will be a new Nintendo Direct later this month.
At least, that's what known Brazilian journalist @phluttilippe has said on X earlier today. Although the journalist has claimed that the Direct will take place by the end of the month, the exact date for the broadcast isn't certain at this point. "There is no Nintendo Direct this week", the journalist wrote on X (Google translated). "End of the month, and as far as I know, the exact date isn't even certain yet."

Last month, Nintendo President Furukawa confirmed that there will be a Direct broadcast this month. During this event, Nintendo won't be talking about the Switch 2. "We will be holding a Nintendo Direct this June regarding the Nintendo Switch software lineup for the latter half of 2024, but please be aware that there will be no mention of the Nintendo Switch successor during that presentation", Furukawa said last month.

While this isn't a confirmation that there indeed won't be a Direct this week, the journalist has correctly revealed Nintendo-related details before official announcements in the past. Also, @phluttilippe was among the first to say that the Switch successor is slated for a release in March 2025, instead of this year. Of course, Nintendo has yet to officially unveil the Switch successor, but Nintendo President Furukawa recently confirmed that the Switch 2 will be announced before April 2025 (before the end of Nintendo's current fiscal year, which runs through March 2025).

We'll update you as soon as we learn more about Nintendo's plans for this month. Stay tuned.

item.title: Snake’s Injuries Will Mark Him Permanently In Metal Gear Solid 3 Remake And Fans Are Stoked
item.content:encoded:
https://kotaku.com/metal-gear-solid-delta-snake-permanent-injuries-1851529537

One of the many amazing games shown off during the 2024 Xbox Showcase on June 9 was the upcoming Metal Gear Solid 3 remake. Officially titled Metal Gear Solid Delta: Snake Eater, the new trailer gave us a fresh look at the gorgeous updated graphics for the 20-year-old game. In tandem, Konami also updated the game’s website with new information, including a fascinating reveal that damage will permanently mark Snake. That feels like a proper Kojima-esque design flourish, and fans are absolutely here for it.

The Week In Games: Pocket Monsters And Simulated Goats

  • Off
  • English

Under the section “Authentic to life portrayals,” the remake’s site details an overhauled damage system focused on lasting wear and tear. Harm to Snake’s body, including bruises and bullet wounds, as well as damage to his clothes, will be reflected in real time. “Any injuries to his actual body will leave their mark permanently,” reads the blurb, “telling a story of each player’s unique journey through the game.”

Despite the jokes about how messed up you will be able to make Snake look by the end of the game, players are genuinely excited about the feature, and especially how it feels so fitting to the franchise’s odd choices. MGS games are known for their weird design flourishes that seemingly have no real purpose beyond complexity. In MGS2 you can watch a cup of ice melt in real-time, and in the original MGS3 you could win a fight against an aging sniper, The End, by simply waiting seven real-world days for him to die of old age. As absurd as these features may sometimes seem, they always add to the depth and immersion of the world. The upgraded damage system of MGS Delta feels like a logical next step for the series, and many see it as a truly Kojima-level choice.

As for how far the new damage system will go, Konami hasn’t given details on what to expect beyond what’s explained in the short blurb on the website. My best guess is that all damage taken by Snake will be able to be healed (this is a video game after all) but will leave a lasting scar, eventually creating a tapestry of mistakes or close calls with death unique to you. Maybe death will leave an exceptionally deep scar on Snake to remind you of when and why you failed. In any case, it’s a fascinating tease of what’s to come in Metal Gear Solid Delta.

item.title: Industry veterans announce Copa City, a football tycoon title and the first from new studio Triple Espresso
item.content:encoded:
https://www.destructoid.com/copa-city-a-football-tycoon-title-from-new-studio-triple-espresso/?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=rss&utm_campaign=copa-city-a-football-tycoon-title-from-new-studio-triple-espresso

Triple Espresso, a brand new game development studio consisting of industry veterans, has announced its first title: Copa City. This game takes football management in a new direction, having you control everything about the city hosting the biggest clubs and matches in the world.

Copa City combines the strategic elements of a tycoon simulator with the electric themes of football to create something that feels altogether new and interesting, much like Football Manager did when the very first entry was released. Just to be clear, this is soccer for you US folks, meaning you’ll be looking after all the hosting requirements and city management that come with major Premier League games and much from the same sport.

Copa City is currently slated for a 2025 release window and is being developed for PC, PS5, and Xbox Series X/S. During the campaign, you’ll manage real-world cities and six fully licensed football clubs playing in them. The clubs include Arsenal FC, FC Bayern Munchen, and CR Flamengo, so definitely some of the bigger names out there.

Your overarching goal with every match is to help the city gear up for the event and even get excited about it. This includes organizing how roadblocks must be set up, advertising, where fans can sit, and more. It reminds me a lot of the final match Leicester had to play in the Premier League in the 2015/16 season.

The team was going to win the league regardless of the outcome, but more people watched it and were excited about it and the ensuring victory parade that occurred after than I’ve ever seen before. Everyone was talking about it, but the amount of management that must have gone into organizing every aspect of the match and everything that followed must have been monumental.

I believe that’s the goal of Copa City: to put you in the shoes of the people working to facilitate that excitement in the best ways possible. You have all the responsibilities that come with keeping people and businesses in the city safe without all the team management, but you’re also rooting for one particular outcome so you can put on a fantastic show.

The game is being developed by veterans from across the industry who have worked on titles such as Watch Dogs, Dying Light 2, and Pure Farming 2018, as well as football experts who have a wealth of knowledge to make the experience feel great for fans of football and strategy games alike.

Copa City is entering a space that the Football Manager and, to a degree, EA Sports FC have owned for over a decade. It’ll be interesting to see if it resonates with fans and can make a dent where fans love stats and want more management options at their fingertips.
